instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.ALL_STS_PWRGD: What is ALL_STS_PWRGD? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_STS_PWRGD, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> in S0 State - no power
threads.message:
Hey everyone, looking for some help here; 

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, I’m in an S0 state, but no power.

I seem to have all the S0 power rails besides vcore.

I do not have <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>. I have checked the pins on <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> and are the following:
<SIGNAL>VMON_Q4_BASE</SIGNAL> = 0v759
<SIGNAL>S0PGD_BJT_GND_R</SIGNAL> = 0v087
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 0v668
<SIGNAL>VMON_Q2_BASE</SIGNAL> = 0v675
<SIGNAL>S0PGD_C</SIGNAL> = 0v128
<SIGNAL>VMON_Q3_BASE</SIGNAL> = 0v675
I’ve replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> and same result

I've also replaced from advice of others: 
Y1915
<CHIP>U1950</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> in S0 State - no power
threads.message:
Do not change anything without a good reason.

<TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> is a redundant protection and can be simplt left out, for test; not really need to put it back.
Its inputs look good, but easy to test in case of doubt.

You didn't specify if all S3/0 voltages are present.
Of course, VCORE cannot appear if <SIGNAL>ALL_STS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is not present.
Remove (one by one) <RESISTOR>R8164</RESISTOR>/65/66/68 and test each time; keep <RESISTOR>R8167</RESISTOR> in place!
Start with <RESISTOR>R8166</RESISTOR>; many times fails (w/o reason) power good from 1V8...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> in S0 State - no power
threads.message: Wow thank you man. After removing the last resistor (<RESISTOR>R8168</RESISTOR>) I got fan spin! Now to put new resistors on

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> in S0 State - no power
threads.message: Okay, after installing another <RESISTOR>R8168</RESISTOR>, no fan spin again

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> in S0 State - no power
threads.message:
How did you think <RESISTOR>R8168</RESISTOR> could be bad???

If DDREG volatge is OK, let <RESISTOR>R8168</RESISTOR> out and check if board works.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> in S0 State - no power
threads.message:
How could I think <RESISTOR>R8168</RESISTOR> was bad? On a wing and a prayer I guess. I saw fan spin and got excited, thinking I found my issue. 
I checked all the voltages going to the line, per your suggestion, with a closer eye this time, and noticed that <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> was 1v08 instead of the expected 1v2 (Initially thinking this was in the margin of error). So After checking the resistor <RESISTOR>R7450</RESISTOR> to make sure it was in spec, I decided to change <TRANSISTOR>Q7430</TRANSISTOR>. Once I did that, I got the 1v2 I was expecting, and board fixed. Thanks again for your help
